document.masterDocTitle: New deep­sea species of Macrostylidae (Asellota: Isopoda: Malacostraca) from the Angola Basin off Namibia, South West Africa

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New deep­sea species of Macrostylidae (Asellota: Isopoda: Malacostraca) from the Angola Basin off Namibia, South West Africa

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype
: ɗ ( 2.5 mm ), Angola Basin, South Atlantic,
16 ° 14.3 ’S
005° 26.8 ’E
–
6 ° 14.9 ’S
005° 26.7 ’E
,
2 July 2000
,
ZMH 40278
; EBS, station 350, 5389 m.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6 .
Macrostylis longipedis
sp. nov. , holotype ɗ (2.5 mm), dorsal and lateral views, antennule, antenna, left mandible, maxillule, maxilliped, pleopods 3, 4.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution: Only known from the Angola Basin, 5389–5395 m .
Etymology : From the Latin words longus (long) combined with pedis (foot); alluding to the extraordinary length of pereopod seven.
Diagnosis: Fourth pereopods shorter than others. Pereopod 7 about twice as long as body. Uropods elongate, very slender, about as long as total body length.
RMd (not illustrated): Similar to left, but without lacinia mobilis, incisor with 3 teeth.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7 .
Macrostylis longipedis
sp. nov. , holotype ɗ (2.5 mm), pereopods 1–5.

FIGURE 8 .
Macrostylis longipedis
sp. nov. , holotype ɗ (2.5 mm), pereopods 6, 7, pleopods 1, 2, uropod.

subSubSection.paragraph: Plp 5 (not illustrated) only 1 small oval lobe.

Remarks .
Macrostylis longipedis
sp. nov. can easily be distinguished from the other species of the genus by the extremely long seventh pereopod, which is more than twice as long as the body. The uropods of
M. longipedis
are slightly longer than the body, much longer than in the other known species of
Macrostylis
, allowing easy identification lasting the absence pereopod 7 . The last two flagellar articles of the male antenna possess a huge number of very long and slender aesthetascs, each of which is about as long as the article itself, another unique character within the genus. Females are not known.
